awd_titl_txt: III: Small: Promoting Reuse and Retargeting in Data Science
awd_abstract_narration:
The past decade has brought a sea change in the availability of data. Devices and data acquisition tools make it easy to acquire new data, cloud hosting and "data lakes" make it easy to centralize and share files, and cloud data analytics and machine learning tools have driven a desire to integrate and extract value from that data. Data scientists must operate within a plethora of datasets, versions, and representations that span users, groups, and organizations. They often end up doing redundant work because they have no effective way of finding appropriate resources to reuse and retarget to new applications. Data scientists need a set of holistic data management tools to find, standardize, and reuse the existing resources in the data lake. The proposed work will address these needs, and it will enhance the widely-used Jupyter Notebook and JupyterLab data science environments. The tools will also be integrated and evaluated with the PI's existing life-science collaborations, with neuroscientists (including the IEEG.org portal with over 3000 users), geneticists, and radiologists. The proposed work will leverage Penn's efforts to involve female students, and those from underrepresented groups, in summer research; and the research will be incorporated into the curriculum of Penn's Data Science Master's program and online degree programs.

The PI will develop the Juneau system, a novel data management platform for data lakes.  It will provide efficient versioned storage of source, intermediate, and final datasets and data products, making it easy to index, search, and compare different results. A rich set of search tools and ranking algorithms for taking an existing table fragment, schema, or task, and finding related tables will make it easier for users to reuse the results of prior work. The project will develop techniques that learn from past data schemas and processing pipelines, and help users design new ones that do not need to start "from scratch," making it easier for users to reuse the data models and tools that were previously developed.  It will also develop techniques for analyzing computations performed by the user community, and developing schemas and representations for sharing, making it easier to promote data modeling based on how data is actually being used.  Finally, the researchers will create models and tools for "retargeting" limited classes of data pipelines from one data processing platform to another, making it easier to share and reuse code across different languages and tools. Juneau will be accessible to a broad user community because it will layer underneath the popular Jupyter Notebook and JupyterLab platform, which can be deployed locally or on the cloud.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: TRUSTEES OF THE UNIVERSITY OF PENNSYLVANIA, THE

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Trustees of the University of Pennsylvania

por.por_cntn:
The Juneau project is designed as an aid to data scientists doing interactive data science, within integrated development environments (such as Visual Studio Code) and computational notebooks (such as Jupyter Notebook, JupyterLab, Colab, AWS SageMaker).  As a data scientist loads or creates tables, the system develops search capabilities to help recommend useful "next actions."

The "next actions" might involve loading a related table -- adding more features or providing more comprehensive training or testing data for machine learning.  They might alternatively involve running a commonly-used function to do data cleaning, feature extraction, etc.  In all cases, the tables and code are based on Juneau's data lake which stores information about past users' data and computation.

Intellectual Merit: The Juneau project developed novel techniques for (1) ranking matches between "search objects" and tables, code, and other data within a data lake; (2) profiling, indexing, storing, and rapidly searching millions of tables; (3) storage of a graph of relationships among the objects in the data lake, including computational steps (provenance) relating objects; (4) machine learning-based methods of estimating the performance of different computations. The project also developed the open-source Juneau codebase.

Broader Impacts. The project served as a nexus for the traning of three PhD students (one female), three Master's students (two female), and one undergraduate who later pursued a PhD. It developed new curricular materials for Penn's CIS 5450 Big Data Analytics course; which were also open-sourced to the OpenDS4All community data science course materials. Technologies from the Juneau system are being experimentally integrated with the widely used open-source Pennsieve.io cloud platform for biomedical data sharing.


Last Modified: 11/28/2023
Modified by: Zachary Ives

Image
  • The basic Juneau system and how it enables indexing and search.
    Yi Zhang and Zachary Ives
    Creative Commons
    Zachary Ives
    Juneau Architecture

The "next actions" might involve loading a related table -- adding more features or providing more comprehensive training or testing data for machine learning. The project also developed the open-source Juneau codebase.
